stories.headline: $9B in greenlit funding in peril
stories.summary: The Senate voted Tuesday to advance President Donald Trump’s request to claw back $9 billion in foreign aid and federal funding for public broadcasting despite the misgivings of some Republicans. The vote was 51-50, with Vice President JD Vance breaking a tie after Sens. Susan Collins, Lisa Murkowski and Mitch McConnell sided with their party and voted with Democrats. Senators must now consider a series of other procedural hurdles and up to 10 hours of debate before a final floor vote; if that succeeds, the legislation would have to return to the House to be considered before Friday’s deadline. The provisions bill is a top priority for the Trump administration, which plans to use the same process to seek deeper cuts in the future if it passes. But some Senate Republicans balked at the cuts, leading Senate Majority Leader John Thune to strip some of them.

stories.headline: U.S. aid cuts deepen Afghans’ woe
stories.summary: Food, health care shortages grow acute as relief all but ends in Afghanistan. In March 2024, international donors delivered boxes of emergency food to his village, Hatam Khail, but the Afghan capital and surrounding areas remain blighted by decades of war and out of basic services. As they waited for snow to melt around their mud brick house and for their cherry tree to blossom, Usman, his wife, and their six sons and grandchildren carefully rationed the donated goods. They expected more food would come during the winter but it never did. Usman, holding out hands cracked by years of hard labor, said that the Taliban-run regime provided nothing. During America’s 20-year war against the Taliban, successive U.S. presidents vowed never to abandon Afghanistan, one of the world’s poorest and most underdeveloped nations. When American troops withdrew in 2021 and the Taliban regained power, the United States remained the country’s largest humanitarian donor, accounting for more than 40 percent of all humanitarian support—helping stave off hunger and support health care providers. That lifeline and but vanished when Donald Trump returned to the White House in January, swiftly announcing a pause in foreign assistance programs that he said were "not aligned with American interests and in many cases" were effectively discontinued.

stories.headline: Falling under AI’s aegis: War and taxes
stories.summary: Elon Musk has receded from Washington but one of his most disruptive ideas about government is surging inside the Trump administration. Artificial intelligence, Musk has said, can do a better job than federal employees at many tasks — a notion being tested by AI projects trying to automate work across nearly every agency in the executive branch. The Federal Aviation Administration is exploring whether AI can be a better air traffic controller. The Pentagon is using AI to help officers distinguish between combatants and civilians in the field, and said Monday that its personnel would begin using the chatbot Grok offered by Musk’s start-up xAI, which is trying to gain a foothold in federal agencies. A central role could soon play a central role in tax audits, airport security screenings and more, according to public documents and interviews with current and former federal workers. Many of these AI programs aim to shrink the federal workforce — continuing the work of Musk’s U.S. DOGE Service, which has cut thousands of government employees. Government AI is also promised to reduce wait times and lower costs to American taxpayers. Government tech watchdogs caution about the risks when AI tools are used in government work, urging robust checks to prevent bias and inaccuracies.

stories.headline: Americans pull back on summer vacations amid warning signs on economy
stories.summary: Americans are downzoning their summer vacations — taking shorter trips, driving instead of flying, and generally staying closer to home in an uncertain economy. Families appear to be pulling back on travel spending, after years of splurging on vacations and other experiences after the pandemic-era shutdowns. Travel households are booking airline tickets or hotel rooms now than they were a year ago. Bank of America data shows the number of people taking vacation time off work in June dropped to its lowest level since the pandemic, according to Labor Department data. There are growing worries about the economy — with new trade and immigration policies taking hold. Many are bracing for a spike in prices from new tariffs, while others are worried about losing their jobs in a slowing labor market. Renewed tariff threats last week — including rates as high as 50 percent on goods from Brazil, Japan and Canada starting August 9 — have added to fears that a new round of inflation may be around the corner. Consumer spending dropped in May, as households put more of their incomes in savings in anticipation of higher costs. In all, Americans expect to spend an average $3,132 on summer vacations this year, about 25 percent less than the $4,199 they set aside last summer, according to an annual survey conducted by Ipsos for Generali Global Assistance. The spending slowdown is real, said Diane Swonk, chief economist at KPMG. Consumers are stressed, and this is where we’re seeing it first: in domestic flights, hotels, and a lot of other service-sector spending. Although the wealthiest Americans are still splurging on international travel and booking hotel rooms that cost $800 a night or more, average consumers are cutting back significantly on vacations to manage costs. Inflation up: Tariffs boosted prices across the economy in June.

stories.headline: GOP’s rift on Epstein continues to widen
stories.summary: One of the leading Republicans on Capitol Hill broke with the Trump administration’s decision not to release the files of deceased sex offender Jeffrey Epstein as the controversy deepened over the handling of an issue that has caused unprecedented division among the GOP base. House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-Louisiana) told right-wing podcaster Benny Johnson on Tuesday that he supported the release of the Epstein files, days after President Donald Trump’s Justice Department said the matter was effectively closed. Johnson is a close Trump ally and has never broken so publicly with the president on an issue.

stories.headline: Atmospheric forces drive deadly flooding in U.S.
stories.summary: In the week and a half since floods killed at least 130 people in Central Texas, heavy rains have filled New York subway stations, submerged busy roadways and drowned two people in a vehicle in New Jersey. Storms have stranded Washington-area motorists. Deadly torrents returned to a flood- and fire-scarred region of New Mexico. And meanwhile, flooding rains have yet to relent in Texas. Experts say downpours and thunderstorms are a familiar signal of summer — but this one has been different. Barely halfway through, it’s already been a hyperactive season of often fatal flooding, with more than twice as many floods as usual so far this July, according to National Weather Service reports. There are varying meteorological forces behind this month’s extreme rainfall, connected to significant amounts of atmospheric moisture pulsing above the country. It is flowing from abnormally warm oceans across the Northern Hemisphere that are likely to stretch elevated flood risks into August, data shows — perhaps into record territory. The conditions are allowing plumes of tropical moisture to stretch into middle latitudes and stagnate there, sending flood risks surging and driving floods in multiple states.

stories.headline: APD chief proposes major shake-up to get more officers on patrol
stories.summary: Austin Police Chief Lisa Davis is planning a sweeping reorganization of the Austin Police Department to reassign dozens of officers from specialized units to street patrol in order to address chronic patrol shortages. The plan aims to relieve long-level patrol shifts and reduce homicide detectives’ overtime hours. The reorganization would slash overtime spending and is being timed amid significant budget shortfalls facing the city government.

stories.headline: 46 minutes between alert, evacuation
stories.summary: The owner of Camp Mystic received a National Weather Service alert about life-threatening flash flooding but camp personnel did not start evacuating children until 46 minutes later. Twenty-five campers and two counselors died when floodwaters hit the camp on July 4. The exact timeline of the evacuation is still being determined, as the weather service sent the flash flood warning at 1:14 a.m. while torrential rains pummeled the Texas Hill Country.

stories.headline: Abbott shocked by flood damage
stories.summary: Texas Governor Greg Abbott expressed shock at the extensive flood damage in the Leander area following flash floods over the Fourth of July weekend that killed at least 131 people across several counties including Travis, Burnet and Williamson. Abbott toured affected areas, provided updates on recovery efforts, and highlighted the extraordinary challenges faced by the state. He also noted ongoing flooding and infrastructure damage.

stories.headline: How Trump plans to undo the Education Department
stories.summary: Education Secretary Linda McMahon is expected to move quickly to implement President Donald Trump's plan to unwind the Education Department following a Supreme Court ruling. The ruling paused a lower court order halting nearly 1,400 layoffs and called into question the legality of Trump's efforts to outsource department operations. McMahon plans to divvy up core functions to other federal agencies as layoffs and restructuring are anticipated.

stories.headline: Epstein conspiracy theories give Trump self-made crisis
stories.summary: As supporters react strongly to the Justice Department's handling of Jeffrey Epstein records release, President Trump faces a crisis fueled by conspiracy theories. His approach to struggling with issues linked to Epstein's connections has drawn criticism and complicated his political situation. Trump has dismissed these concerns but they continue to affect his standing with some voters.

stories.headline: Ukraine citizens welcome promise of US aid
stories.summary: Ukrainian citizens have expressed relief at President Donald Trump's pledge of increased U.S.-made weapons amid ongoing conflict with Russia. However, some view Trump's 50-day ultimatum for Russian President Vladimir Putin as too long. The article discusses the strategic importance of arms aid, Ukraine's resistance at the front lines, and varying opinions on recent sanctions and political negotiations.

stories.headline: 'A lot of heartache, a lot of sadness'
stories.summary: Jasmine Holmquist, widow of a Marine killed in the 2015 Chattanooga terrorist attack, shares her difficult journey toward healing. Her young daughter Wrylin never met her biological father, who was a hero despite the tragedy. Jasmine works to communicate with her daughter about their loss and honors the fallen servicemen at memorial events. The story highlights the ongoing emotional impact on families affected by the attack.

stories.headline: Chattanooga officials consider tax increase
stories.summary: Chattanooga city staffers discussed historic property value increases and proposed a property tax rate hike to fund fire and police raises. City officials noted a $14 billion increase in property value over the past four years. The city's property tax rate was lowered in 2023 after a countywide appraisal, but further increases may be considered to account for rising values and additional city revenue needs. Tennessee law requires local government approval for such increases.

stories.headline: June inflation rises; observers say it's an effect of tariffs
stories.summary: Recent data shows inflation rose 2.7% in the past 12 months through June, reaching the highest annual inflation rate since February. Critics link the rise to President Donald Trump's tariff policies, which increased costs on imported goods, affecting consumer prices for housing, food, and gasoline. Most economists expect tariffs to keep inflation elevated as import taxes raise costs for American consumers. Prices for apparel and furniture saw notable increases. However, there is ongoing debate, with some tariffs paused or postponed.

stories.headline: Housing strategy goes to council
stories.summary: The Des Moines City Council unanimously approved its first citywide housing strategy, outlining a detailed vision to improve housing affordability, neighborhood stability, and quality of homes over the next decade. The plan aims to keep Des Moines attractive and affordable amidst competition with fast-growing suburbs. It serves as a roadmap rather than binding law, guiding zoning decisions, funding, and housing initiatives. The strategy follows controversy after calls to pause support for affordable housing projects funded through Low-Income Housing Tax Credits but ultimately supports projects under certain conditions.

stories.headline: A big, beautiful break for Grinnell College
stories.summary: Grinnell College officials were anticipating a $30 million tax hike under President Donald Trump's proposed massive tax cut but instead will get a tax cut. A new tax legislation affects private liberal arts colleges like Grinnell with an endowment tax cut, despite originally expected tax hikes tied to a proposed increase on large college endowments under Trump's budget bill. However, new legislation applies only to schools with more than 3,000 students, exempting Grinnell as it has about 1,750 students. Grinnell has been paying about $2.4 million per year in taxes under a 1.4% rate and will not see an endowment tax increase.

stories.headline: Despite military alliance, Australia leader snubs Trump for China
stories.summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has emphasized stronger economic ties with China over alignment with the United States amid ongoing tensions. During a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping, Albanese highlighted Australia's significant trade with China and a willingness to engage through scheduled summits, signaling a pivot that some interpret as snubbing Trump-era policies favoring U.S. alliances in the region.

stories.headline: Monk's No. 81 headed to immortality at long last
stories.summary: No Washington Commanders player will ever wear the number 81 again, as the team plans to retire the jersey of wide receiver Monk, honoring his legacy and contributions. Monk's number retirement follows that of other Commanders legends and reflects his lasting impact on the team. Despite not having his number retired immediately after his career, the ceremony will cement his place in franchise history.

stories.headline: Trump fights borderline asylum Supreme Court asked to define migrant 'arrival'
stories.summary: The Supreme Court has been asked to clarify the definition of 'arrival' in the context of migrant asylum claims at the U.S.-Mexico border. The Trump administration is contesting a lower court ruling that requires migrants to enter the U.S. border to claim asylum. The case centers around how migrants who cross between official ports of entry should be treated legally, with consequential implications for immigration policy and border enforcement.

stories.headline: Silence on Epstein exposes rift within Trump voter base
stories.summary: The Justice Department's refusal to release additional files related to sexual predator Jeffrey Epstein has created a deep divide within President Trump's MAGA base. Some Trump supporters insist Epstein was killed in jail, while the Justice Department and FBI deny any such evidence. The ongoing secrecy frustrates many in the base, who feel promised disclosures will not be fully delivered as the 2024 campaign progresses.

stories.headline: Spiking lawsuit payouts put state's self-insurance fund $1B in the red
stories.summary: Lawsuit payouts by the state of Washington surged to a new high of more than $506 million in the latest fiscal year, mostly due to claims from children in the foster care system. This severe rise in payouts drained the state's self-insurance fund, projecting a deficit of over $1 billion, according to a top state budget official. A temporary cash deficiency measure is authorized through June 2027 to address the shortfall.

stories.headline: PCC makes downtown comeback with downsized ambitions
stories.summary: PCC Community Markets, after doubts about returning to downtown Seattle, marked its reopening with a scaled-back model. A line of customers waited at the new store located on the ground floor of Rainier Tower at Fourth Avenue and Union Street. Although smaller than before, the market aims to serve Seattle's grocery needs while remaining financially sustainable through this more modest approach.

stories.headline: Seattle-area inflation up in June as tariffs start to take toll
stories.summary: Inflation in the Seattle area slightly increased in June, driven by the impacts of tariffs on imported goods and higher costs for essentials like food and energy. Overall costs rose 2.7% compared to the same month last year, marking a 1 percentage point increase from April. Experts are closely monitoring the effects of tariffs and trade policies on inflation trends in the region.

stories.headline: WSDOT's plan of pain: Years of I-5 lane closures in Seattle to begin this weekend
stories.summary: Seattle faces years of disruption as the Washington State Department of Transportation (WSDOT) begins the first stage of a lengthy project involving closures of all 30 northbound lanes on the Interstate 5 Ship Canal Bridge. The first wave starting this weekend will last until July 21 and will affect traffic northbound from Interstate 90 to Northeast 45th Street, causing delays and requiring drivers to navigate alternate routes. The project will continue with intermittent closures until 2027.

stories.headline: Senate votes to advance bill to cut $9B from budget
stories.summary: Senate Republicans advanced President Donald Trump's request to cancel $9 billion in previously approved spending amid concerns about its impact on the impoverished. The Senate vote was closely split, with Vice President breaking the tie. A final vote is expected Wednesday, and the bill aims to reduce budget expenditures before another veto might be issued by the president.

stories.headline: Citizen checks at Head Start
stories.summary: Head Start providers nationwide are now required to verify the citizenship and immigration status of children before enrollment, following a new rule by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services effective July 10. This policy aims to block undocumented children from accessing the program for the first time in its 60-year history. Michigan Head Start Association leadership is awaiting guidance on implementation and emphasizes the importance of providing clarity for families and staff.

stories.headline: GM takes turn at Orion Assembly away from EVs
stories.summary: General Motors announced a strategic shift at its Orion Township plant, delaying plans to produce electric vehicles like the Cadillac Escalade, Chevrolet Silverado, and GMC Sierra light-duty pickups there. Despite receiving $480 million in state grant funds to expand EV production, GM stated it will not build EVs at Orion but will support Factory Zero for electric trucks. The move aims to focus on long-term profitability and strengthen manufacturing footprint in Michigan.

stories.headline: Hidden secrets of MI lakes revealed
stories.summary: Researchers have rescued a data trove containing detailed information on 1,300 Michigan lakes, originally gathered on yellowing index cards since 1921. The Michigan Department of Natural Resources digitized about 450,000 card transcriptions with help from worldwide volunteers. This electronic resource now enables the study of changes in fish sizes, species, water temperature, and other lake aspects over decades.

stories.headline: What happens after ICE arrests immigrants?
stories.summary: The article details the journey of Frescia Garro Pinchi, a Peruvian woman arrested by ICE agents and detained despite having no criminal record. It explores the challenges immigrants face after ICE arrests, including prolonged detentions, legal struggles, and threats to family stability. The story underscores the role of legal advocates like attorney Jordan Weiner who provide emergency counsel in these high-profile cases.

stories.headline: Police killings fall in California, rise in red states
stories.summary: California law enforcement officers killed fewer people in 2024 compared to previous years and national trends, according to analysis of statistics from the California Department of Justice. While California and some other states saw reductions in police killings, red states have seen an increase over the last decade. The article highlights legislative efforts to reduce racial profiling and lethal encounters in California.

stories.headline: Muni calls for caution on big tax measure
stories.summary: San Francisco budget officials aim to address Muni's $322 million deficit by proposing big tax measures on the ballot, but caution has been advised due to the financial risks to transit services. City Controller Greg Wagner warned that while new revenue sources like sales and parcel taxes are possible, there is a danger of service cuts affecting recovery momentum. The letter marks the last stage of the Muni Funding Working Group's efforts involving multiple stakeholders to address the financial predicaments of public transit in San Francisco.

stories.headline: Asian eateries save another local mall
stories.summary: Serramonte Center in Daly City has successfully attracted crowds by opening a Korean food market called Jagalchi, which revitalized the mall previously struggling with big-box store closures. This shift to include popular Asian businesses has helped the mall draw nearly 100,000 people on its opening weekend, while plans for further new restaurants and food businesses indicate continued growth in this retail environment adapting to changing consumer habits.

stories.headline: Trump's Leap To Kyiv’s Side Flips G.O.P.
stories.summary: A change in stance by former House Republicans, influenced by President Trump’s 'America First' policy, has led to a significant shift in congressional voting on aid for Ukraine. Many Republicans now oppose weapons shipments to Ukraine, signaling a new divide within the party and impacting President Biden's foreign policy.

stories.headline: A Thai River Runs Toxic as Mining Flourishes Across a Border
stories.summary: The Kok River in Thailand and Myanmar is becoming dangerously polluted due to arsenic and other toxic metals from unregulated rare earth mining in Myanmar. This contamination threatens the health of local residents and wildlife, with authorities slow to inform the public or address the environmental damage.

stories.headline: Wes Anderson’s Easter Egg? A High School Pal.
stories.summary: Filmmaker Michael Maggart, who met Wes Anderson in high school, has been a recurring but uncredited figure in Anderson's films. Maggart, a fastidious filmmaker himself, supports Anderson's projects though he does not have acting credits, appearing in films like 'Asteroid City' and enjoying connections within Hollywood.

stories.headline: Allies of Trump Teamed to Fell A School Head
stories.summary: The Jefferson Council, comprising conservative-leaning University of Virginia alumni, campaigned against the university president James E. Ryan for his support of campus diversity initiatives. They opposed new directions on diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) efforts and aimed to influence governance under Glenn Youngkin's term as governor of Virginia.

stories.headline: The Global A.I. Divide
stories.summary: As nations compete to develop artificial intelligence technologies, a growing gap has emerged worldwide. This divide concerns the economic, technological, and security implications as leading countries and regions invest heavily, potentially reshaping global power structures and industries.

stories.headline: ‘Severance’ Leads Emmy Nods
stories.summary: The dystopian workplace series 'Severance' received 27 nominations for the Emmy Awards, including one for best drama. The show's unique premise and critical acclaim have earned it significant recognition in the television industry.

stories.headline: President Fueled Conspiracists. Will They Revolt Over Epstein?
stories.summary: President Trump’s past denials of conspiracy theories about Jeffrey Epstein have caused division among his political supporters, with some followers continuing to believe in conspiracies despite investigations and evidence. This ongoing conflict over Epstein-related issues remains a sensitive topic in political circles and among Trump's base.

stories.headline: Rising Inflation Signals Hazards in Trump Tariffs
stories.summary: President Trump's tariffs are causing higher prices for American consumers, particularly on appliances and furniture due to increased costs from imports and supply chain disruptions. An inflation report highlights the undercutting impact of tariffs on consumer products, contributing to worries about economic burdens on Americans.

stories.headline: Force Behind Precise GPS
stories.summary: Daniel Kleppner developed an atomic clock essential for global positioning systems (GPS), aiding the precise navigation and timing technologies used worldwide. His work has had a vital impact on modern technology and transportation.

stories.headline: Minnesota Yacht Club is ready to rock on
stories.summary: The Minnesota Yacht Club music festival is set to take place on Harriet Island with headliners Red Hot Chili Peppers and Joan Jett, among others. The event marks a return after flooding impacted the Mississippi River region. The Parks and Recreation department collaborated with organizers to prepare for the event, which expects around 35,000 attendees with a lineup including other popular bands. The festival brings excitement and a strong community atmosphere to St. Paul.

stories.headline: Former Twins pitcher is convicted of murder
stories.summary: Daniel Serafini, a former Major League Baseball player and first-round draft pick by the Twins, has been found guilty of first-degree murder for the fatal shooting of his in-laws in 2021. The conviction followed court testimony and evidence presented that connects Serafini to the crime. Serafini's defense and arguments appeared unsuccessful as he was convicted of this serious crime.

stories.headline: Migrants will not get bond hearings
stories.summary: The Trump administration has declared that immigrants who entered the United States illegally are no longer eligible for bond hearings while facing deportation. ICE director Todd M. Lyons instructed officers to detain immigrants during the entire removal process, potentially for months or years, even if their cases are still ongoing. This policy change affects millions of immigrants, sparking concerns about prolonged detentions and the inability to request bond hearings prior to immigration judge proceedings.

stories.headline: Testimonies conflict in Mitchell trial
stories.summary: DFL Senator Nicole Mitchell's stepmother, Carol Mitchell, struggles to recall details and answer questions regarding an alleged break-in at her home. The defense attorneys suggest Carol Mitchell may be experiencing cognitive decline and memory issues. This inconsistency complicates the legal proceedings as more conflicting statements arise over events concerning a burglary charge linked to the senator's stepmother's home.

stories.headline: Boelter indicted on murder counts
stories.summary: Federal prosecutors revealed new details in the case against Vance Boelter, accused of assassinating Minnesota lawmaker Melissa Hortman and her husband Mark. The indictment includes multiple charges such as stalking, fatal shootings, and attempted shootings involving Boelter and his involvement in a political violence conspiracy. Authorities describe Boelter as having a troubled mindset with political violence motivations and extremism. Prosecutors are exploring a possible death penalty, while investigations continue around the motive.

stories.headline: Beijing Meets GDP Target
stories.summary: China successfully met its gross domestic product growth target for the second quarter with a 5.2% year-over-year increase. This milestone highlights recovery and economic strength despite ongoing global challenges and pressure from trade tensions. Economic statistics reflect steady growth as China manages its development goals.

stories.headline: Europe Helped Foster Trump’s Putin Pivot
stories.summary: After Russian airstrikes on Ukrainian cities late in July, President Trump called Chancellor Merkel of Germany to express frustration over Vladimir Putin's actions. Despite initial impatience, Trump realized the need for diplomacy and accepted offers of German funds to aid Ukraine. The EU’s role was crucial in shaping Trump’s approach to the conflict with Russia.

stories.headline: Wildfire Turns Grand Canyon Into a Hellscape
stories.summary: Arizona fire crews struggled Tuesday to contain the rapidly spreading Dragon Bravo Fire along the North Rim of the Grand Canyon. The National Park Service faced criticism for not aggressively attacking the blaze early on which allowed the wildfire to escalate.

stories.headline: A Rare-Earth Play to End China’s Dominance
stories.summary: Pentagon and Apple have made deals to support MP Materials’ ambition of turbocharging U.S. rare-earth metal production to reduce reliance on China. Despite recent investments and government support, challenges remain in revitalizing the American rare-earth supply chain, essential for technology and defense applications.

stories.headline: President Bets Shifting Strategy On Trade Can Help Negotiations
stories.summary: President Trump expressed confidence that changing his approach to trade negotiations by extending deadlines and applying more pressure would help keep trading partners in suspense and improve outcomes. Despite risks of a downward spiral, he believes this tactic can aid in securing better deals and managing allies' expectations in ongoing trade talks with Mexico and other partners.

stories.headline: Inflation Picks Up To 2.7% As Tariffs Seep In
stories.summary: Inflation accelerated to 2.7% in June, signaling that companies are beginning to pass tariff costs to consumers. Consumer prices rose 2.7% year-over-year, with core inflation remaining steady. Economists are divided on the impact of the president's trade war on prices, while some prices for volatile food and energy fell. These inflationary pressures have raised concerns about ongoing economic resilience.

stories.headline: Feds probe UM over foreign gift disclosures
stories.summary: The U.S. Department of Education is investigating the University of Michigan for alleged violations of federal disclosure laws related to foreign gifts and grants. The probe focuses on Chinese researchers with connections to the university charged with smuggling biological materials. Allegations include incomplete and untimely reports of gifts and contracts, with financial contributions from China totaling about $250,000 and over $86 million in undisclosed submissions.

stories.headline: Tigers’ special show goes national
stories.summary: The Detroit Tigers had six players selected as All-Stars in the Major League Baseball All-Star Game held in Atlanta. The players, including Tarik Skubal, Gleyber Torres, Javier Greene, and Javier Báez, wore home and road jerseys from their teams in the midseason showcase. The event celebrates top baseball talent and highlights the Tigers’ strong presence in the league again this season.

stories.headline: AI poised for bigger role in government
stories.summary: Elon Musk has withdrawn from Washington, but the Trump administration is integrating artificial intelligence more deeply into federal operations. The Federal Aviation Administration is exploring AI to improve air traffic control, including using the chatbot Grok by Musk's start-up xAI. AI technologies may soon have roles in tax audits, airport security screenings, and other areas by analyzing documents and interviews with federal workers, potentially reducing workforce size.

stories.headline: 'Gas station heroin' draws regulators’ attention
stories.summary: Officials in Metro Detroit are raising concerns over kratom, a chemical derivative of a natural substance similar to opioids, which is widely available at gas stations and smoke shops. Kratom is a tropical tree from Southeast Asia whose leaves produce stimulant and sedative effects, which in high doses may be harmful. Authorities are worried about easy access to kratom for younger populations and are calling for better labeling and education about its risks.

stories.headline: Report: Inflation sped up in June
stories.summary: Inflation rates have accelerated in June, with consumer prices rising 2.7% compared to a year ago, driven largely by increasing tariffs and higher costs of goods such as clothes and appliances. The Federal Reserve faces pressure to balance inflation control with economic growth as President Trump influences trade policies contributing to the rise.

stories.headline: GOP senators advance bill to slash funds
stories.summary: Senate Republicans advanced a bill to cancel $9 billion in previously approved spending by President Biden to cut federal programs, including public broadcasting and HIV/AIDS initiatives. The legislation follows ongoing discussions about government spending on various programs, with the White House expressing concerns but focusing on other priorities.

stories.headline: Little Rock board approves curfew
stories.summary: The Little Rock Board of Directors unanimously approved a curfew ordinance requiring minors under 18 to remain off the streets from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. unless accompanied by a parent or involved in city-sponsored activities. The measure aims to reduce crimes related to underage presence in certain areas and takes effect in September.

stories.headline: Funding cuts threaten Arkansas' public media
stories.summary: Senator Cliff Schaff highlights concerns over potential funding cuts for public broadcasting, which could affect Arkansas' public media services. Public media leaders are actively advocating against proposed budget reductions as they play a critical role in serving rural communities and providing a valuable news source.

stories.headline: Trump talks tech, energy spending at summit
stories.summary: President Donald Trump discussed investments in energy technology and artificial intelligence at the Pennsylvania Energy and Innovation Summit. Emphasizing a $90 billion investment in state projects, Trump engaged with Senator David McCormick and highlighted America's leadership in innovation and green technologies.

stories.headline: Tasteful tomato
stories.summary: George Zahradka, the owner of Zahradka Family Farm, is featured taking a bite from a tomato he picked on his farm in Essex, demonstrating local agricultural produce and fresh farming practices.

stories.headline: More electric school buses coming to area
stories.summary: The Maryland Energy Administration has announced more than $12 million in grants to add electric school buses and charging infrastructure in seven districts, part of a broader effort to modernize the area's school transportation and reduce environmental impact.

stories.headline: Maryland charter schools fear closures
stories.summary: School leaders are expressing concerns about proposed state regulations that they say could force schools to close, including an increase in administrative costs, raising fears of charter school closures across Maryland.

stories.headline: Saint Agnes nurses plan Baltimore strike
stories.summary: Saint Agnes nurses are planning a strike in Baltimore in response to ongoing frustrations over staffing shortages, patient care, and stalled contract negotiations with hospital management.

stories.headline: Maryland's loans to fired federal employees draw mixed reviews
stories.summary: About 60 former federal workers have applied for a one-time $700 loan that Maryland Governor Wes Moore announced last month to soften the blow for those losing jobs during President Donald Trump's overhaul of the federal government. The loans aim to provide some relief to about 7,100 federal employees fired or laid off. However, many expect to lose more than 11,000 civilian federal jobs in the coming months and fear the $700 won't be enough to sustain them for more than a week. The loan terms come with strict limits and borrowers must repay the $700 within 180 calendar days, with an option for a 90-day extension. The loan is a morale boost but the expected amount appears insufficient for some affected workers.

stories.headline: Baltimore Police raid drug markets after overdoses
stories.summary: Baltimore Police charged five people with narcotics offenses after a raid in response to a wave of overdoses in West Baltimore. Authorities found narcotics after a raid of what they describe as an open-air drug market around the corner from last week's mass overdose event. Five arrests were made, but police did not say whether the drug arrests were related to the overdoses in Penn North. Authorities confirmed no arrests had been made in those overdose cases, but at least 27 people had been hospitalized from the incidents. Police continue to monitor drug dealing hotspots more closely and arrest alleged dealers and seize illicit substances in various raids.

stories.headline: Cop oversight board seeks more power
stories.summary: Baltimore's Police Accountability Board (PAB) is calling for subpoena power over the city's police department to help resolve cases of officer misconduct against residents. PAB chairman Jamal Turner urged the Baltimore City Council to grant investigative and subpoena power to the PAB after complaints of police misconduct cases involving the public directed at the Baltimore Police Department's internal investigations. The PAB is still hearing some pending misconduct cases but cannot take on new ones. Turner said the PAB would recommend that the ACC investigate complaints filed with the PAB and advise on disciplinary action. Independent investigatory power would allow the PAB to launch and conduct its own investigations into misconduct cases.

stories.headline: Locust Point residents fed up with ships' noise, pollution
stories.summary: Local McCoy sat on a couch in his Locust Point townhouse, where a painting of two military ships hung on the wall above him. The ships — the SS Antares and SS Denebola — were longtime neighbors of McCoy, docked at the pier directly across from his back deck for nearly a decade. McCoy, secretary and treasurer of a nearby HOA, and neighbors remember the ships for their quiet, subtle presence. The ships' generators have diminished their quality of life due to incessant hum to flood the living room — an app on his phone reads 70 decibels. It's just causing me stress and anxiety. The ships, under the direction of the U.S. Department of Transportation's Maritime Administration (MARAD), are running on generator until they can transition to shore power. The initial estimate was July 1, but a MARAD spokesperson last week said it could now take up to six months. This project remains a high priority for MARAD, and they are actively working to expedite the process.

stories.headline: Rocky Road
stories.summary: A Baltimore preservation group criticized city officials over what it called the 'degradation' of one of Baltimore's most historic streets, now, citing safety, the city is taking steps to rectify what it says was a temporary repair as workers remove asphalt from historic Thames Street in Fells Point.

stories.headline: GOP looks to tweak request by Trump for spending cuts
stories.summary: Senate Republicans worked Tuesday to slightly scale back President Donald Trump's request to cancel $9.4 billion in previously approved spending as they tried to build momentum for the package before a key test vote. The amended package removes proposed cuts to a program known as PEPFAR that is credited with saving millions of lives since its creation under then-President George W. Bush to combat HIV/AIDS. The president is looking to claw back money for foreign aid programs targeted by his Department of Government Efficiency and for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, while preserving about $400 million for PEPFAR. Trump is ramping up pressure on Senate Republicans to support stripping federal funding from public broadcasters NPR and PBS.

stories.headline: In the spotlight, a face of immigration
stories.summary: Marcelo Gomes da Silva, an 18-year-old Brazilian detained by ICE in Massachusetts, has become a public figure representing immigration issues. After six days in detention, Gomes shared his experiences in interviews and public appearances, navigating the challenges of his family's immigration status and the public attention. His story highlights the complexities and human impact of immigration policies in the state.

stories.headline: Shelter food deal raises questions
stories.summary: The Valley Opportunity Council, a Chicopee nonprofit, awarded a multimillion-dollar shelter food contract to a board member's company without a competitive bidding process. Key Food, owned by Tony Diaz, a board member with prior ties to the nonprofit as a volunteer, won the contract to provide meals to shelter residents and migrant families. Officials became aware after receiving an anonymous complaint, raising concerns about transparency and oversight in managing shelter food services in Massachusetts.

stories.headline: With Boston voters checked out, mayoral campaigns battle on the air
stories.summary: Less than two months before Boston's mayoral race, candidates are focusing on television, radio, and digital advertising to capture voter attention amid low engagement. Political consultants note voters are more focused on summer activities than politics, making campaigns increasingly dependent on airwaves to communicate their messages and connect with the electorate. The battle for voter attention intensifies as the election approaches.

stories.headline: After fire, increased scrutiny of assisted living
stories.summary: Massachusetts officials advocate for new regulations and financing for affordable assisted living homes following a deadly fire at Gabriel House in Fall River, which killed nine elderly residents and sent 30 to hospitals. Officials emphasize the difficulty of enhancing care due to insufficient funding and the reliance on Medicaid and state programs for most residents. There are about 20 similar affordable homes in Massachusetts, with ongoing legislative efforts to impose stricter conditions for safety and care in such facilities.

stories.headline: Tax-free weekend
stories.summary: Annual back-to-school tax-free weekend will be held from Friday through Sunday, allowing parents and students to save on school supplies, clothing, computers, and books. Decatur City Schools Deputy Superintendent Yvette Evans highlights the benefit for families needing to prepare for the new school year. The tax-free holiday is recognized by the Alabama Department of Revenue and is expected to help many local municipalities including Decatur, Athens, Moulton, Madison, and Huntsville, which also allow local sales taxes to be waived during this period.

stories.headline: Vet killed in WWII returns to family
stories.summary: More than 80 years after Pvt. Mack Kidd was killed fighting Japanese troops in Burma during WWII, his remains will be brought home to Lawrence County for burial next week. Kidd, who died during the Siege of Myitkyina in 1944, was originally buried in a mass grave in Myitkyina before being moved to a cemetery in India and later to the National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific in Honolulu. Advances in DNA testing confirmed a match with Kidd's nephew, leading to this final return, ensuring he rests beside his family.

stories.headline: Employees say watchdog is now toothless
stories.summary: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) has been criticized by some current and former employees for failing to effectively enforce laws protecting consumers from financial services abuse. Over 15 years, the CFPB returned nearly $21 billion to victims, but recent leadership and policy shifts have weakened its oversight and enforcement capacity under the current directive, notably since President Trump's administration. Employees report constraints on speaking publicly about their work and declining action on wrongdoing, raising concerns about the agency's future effectiveness.

stories.headline: Megabill secures NASA funds
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has approved a major tax breaks bill that includes billions of dollars flowing to NASA projects key to Huntsville's space economy. Funding secures programs for the Space Launch System and Orion capsule that were previously in jeopardy due to budget cuts. The Space Launch System, a heavy-lift launch vehicle for manned moon missions, will receive $4.1 billion for Artemis missions through 2029. Total NASA funding in Alabama's Marshall Space Flight Center area will near $10 billion, allocated for Artemis and Moon to Mars programs, with advocacy from Senator Katie Britt and others protecting space agencies.

stories.headline: High-fives for bears
stories.summary: At the St. Louis Zoo, visitors interact playfully with twin polar bear cubs, Kallu and Kallik, by offering high-fives. The bears swam energetically in their exhibit, providing an engaging experience for zoo guests. The twins had recently arrived from the Toledo Zoo and Aquarium, enhancing the zoo's attraction and offering unique opportunities for visitors to connect with wildlife.

stories.headline: Audit cites issues in voucher program
stories.summary: A new audit report highlights that Missouri Treasurer Vivek Malek failed to properly oversee the state's private school voucher program as required by state regulations. The program, expanded by recent legislation signed by Governor Mike Kehoe, has lacked proper monitoring and review procedures, raising concerns about errors and noncompliance going undetected. Officials are calling for improved oversight processes to ensure accountability and proper management of scholarship funds.

stories.headline: Baseball tradition getting 'fun' dose of Banana Ball
stories.summary: A new fast-paced style of baseball called Banana Ball is gaining popularity in St. Louis, with baseball legends Albert Pujols and Javier Molina participating in a game that emphasizes fun and excitement. The format includes unique rules designed to speed up the game, appeal to fans, and create an entertaining atmosphere. The Bananas, a team playing this style, are also attracting notable appearances and comedic performances to enhance the experience.

stories.headline: Tariffs pushing inflation higher
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs are causing inflation to rise by increasing costs across various sectors including groceries, clothing, furniture, and appliances. Consumer prices rose 2.7% in June compared to a year earlier, with a monthly increase of 0.3% from May to June, despite some easing in certain areas like energy and food prices. The inflation increase is partly due to the broader economic impact of these tariffs, which has led to a mix of cost-push inflation and a volatile price environment.

stories.headline: Gazans struggle to find water after deadly strike
stories.summary: The Manasra family in Gaza City is facing extreme hardship as they struggle to obtain enough water for drinking and washing following a deadly strike that hit a Gaza water distribution point on July 13. With limited access to clean water compounded by a blockade and fuel shortage, public health is severely impacted, and the family fears worsening conditions including disease and lack of medical aid.

stories.headline: Canada struggled to advise on Trump’s trans policies
stories.summary: Over two months, Canadian officials faced challenges advising Canadians traveling to the US about policies related to President Donald Trump’s executive order on gender identity. The order’s recognition of only two sexes and requirements for sex designation in documents complicated Canada's travel advisories, as officials balanced protecting citizens and maintaining diplomatic relations with the US. Discussions also covered impacts on Canadian permanent residents.

stories.headline: Receive a call from the FBI? Agency says it’s OK to hang up
stories.summary: The FBI warns citizens not to fall for scams involving callers pretending to be FBI agents demanding money or personal information. The bureau clarifies it never demands payment over the phone and advises hanging up immediately on suspicious calls. Citizens are encouraged to report such scams to the Internet Criminal Complaint Center. The alert aims to protect the public from fraudulent activities that misuse the FBI's name to exploit individuals.

stories.headline: Which states are the best, and worst, at tackling plastic pollution?
stories.summary: A new nationwide ranking by Ocean Conservancy grades states based on their laws addressing plastic pollution. California scored highest, recognized for strong policies on plastic bag bans and producer accountability, while Mississippi ranked lowest. The report highlights a general lack of sufficient single-use plastic regulations nationwide, with only a fraction of states showing progress, and stresses the importance of lawmakers enacting effective measures to reduce plastic waste.

stories.headline: Michigan joins lawsuit over frozen education funds
stories.summary: Michigan has joined 22 other states in a lawsuit against the Trump administration for freezing $171 million in education funds vital for after-school and summer programs. Attorney General Dana Nessel expressed concern that the freeze could disrupt plans for the academic year, particularly impacting migrant workers' children. The suit alleges the funding freeze violates statutes and urges the government to restore the support promptly to avoid chaos for schools and local education agencies.

stories.headline: In response to L.A. raids, parents prepare for the worst
stories.summary: Parents in the Inland Empire and Riverside County are preparing for the possibility of their children being separated from them due to immigration raids. Families are making emergency care plans and considering giving up their children to avoid deportation. The number of immigrant parents seeking emergency arrangements has risen sharply since recent deportation actions.

stories.headline: Half of National Guard in L.A. being sent home
stories.summary: Almost half of the nearly 4,000 National Guard soldiers deployed to Los Angeles for immigration raids are being sent home following a prolonged legal battle over the deployment's legality and protests. The Pentagon justified the troop deployment as necessary amid escalating immigration enforcement, despite backlash from local and state officials.

stories.headline: State hit hard by weather service cuts
stories.summary: California's National Weather Service offices are facing staff shortages due to federal cuts, raising concerns about the state's ability to forecast and respond to worsening fire seasons and extreme weather. The staffing shortfalls have led to reliance on neighboring offices and may impact decision-making during hazardous weather events. Trump administration officials have denied that the cuts imperil weather operations.

stories.headline: Inflation fueled by tariffs starts to emerge
stories.summary: Consumer prices rose 2.7% in June from the previous year, marking the highest inflation rate in four months, partly driven by tariffs on furniture, clothing, and other goods. The increase adds pressure on the Federal Reserve to consider tighter monetary policies, with economists noting core inflation prices remain elevated.

stories.headline: Wildfire defense sprinklers: Boon or bane?
stories.summary: Some residents have installed wildfire defense sprinklers around their homes to protect against fires, with some claiming the systems saved their property. However, experts warn these sprinklers might discourage timely evacuations due to a false sense of security. The debate continues over the technology’s effectiveness in enhancing wildfire safety.

stories.headline: Nextdoor doesn't want to be the 'boring' app
stories.summary: Nextdoor, the neighborhood social network, is working to reinvent itself and shed its dull image. The platform, which had surged during the pandemic, is introducing new features aimed at improving community engagement and adapting to a post-pandemic world. The co-founder emphasizes the platform's ongoing evolution to stay relevant amid growing competition.

stories.headline: Plum and red chile jam with no canning required
stories.summary: A recipe or food feature highlighting the making of plum and red chile jam that does not require traditional canning methods, offering a fresh take on preserving flavors.

stories.headline: Schwarber swings All-Star with 3-for-3 performance
stories.summary: Phillies slugger Kyle Schwarber went 3-for-3 for the National League in the first use of the All-Star Game home run swing-off tiebreaker, contributing significantly to the game's excitement.

stories.headline: Laguna Fire 40% contained
stories.summary: The Laguna Fire, burning in New Mexico, has reached 40% containment, easing some concerns but the situation remains under close monitoring.

stories.headline: Truth took long time to come out about Trinity blast
stories.summary: The wives of the Pajarito Plateau area assessed health changes in their husbands after the Trinity blast in 1945 but initially received reassurances. Early media reports echoed government lies about the accidental explosion of ammunition at Alamogordo. It took decades for the truth about the atomic bomb explosion and its health effects to be fully acknowledged. The article revisits the initial news coverage from local newspapers like the Albuquerque Tribune and El Paso Herald-Post.

stories.headline: Instant Flash, Slow Burn: Effects of Trinity Test still haunting New Mexico after 80 years
stories.summary: The article reflects on the 80th anniversary of the Trinity Test, the first atomic bomb test, and its ongoing impact on New Mexico. The test, which took place at White Sands Missile Range in Southern New Mexico, unleashed nuclear physicists' secrets and caused lasting environmental and societal effects. Early reports attempted to cover the government’s secrecy about the accident and its consequences, but truth about the blast and its fallout took a long time to emerge.

stories.headline: Murder conviction in Romero case voided
stories.summary: The New Mexico Supreme Court issued a split decision invalidating the first-degree felony murder conviction of Robert Romero in a 2018 shooting. The decision was based on the definition of 'structure' related to burglary charges, finding that a covered porch or patio is not considered a structure under state statute, which impacted the underlying felony charge. The ruling means that Romero's murder conviction has been voided because prosecutors had elevated the charge improperly from burglary to first-degree murder. Romero was convicted of killing Jones during a burglary at his home in Santa Fe.

stories.headline: US weapons ready to ship in deal to supply Ukraine via NATO
stories.summary: US Patriot air defense systems, missiles and ammunition among American-made weapons NATO allies will purchase under an arms deal brokered by President Donald Trump to help Ukraine defend itself from Russia. The deal ensures immediate shipment of nearly all weapons to Ukraine to reinforce their military stockpiles, maintaining confidentiality on specifics. President Trump said the deal was very lucrative for the US and NATO Secretary-general expressed readiness.

stories.headline: Inflation accelerated in June as tariffs pushed up prices
stories.summary: Inflation increased in June due to President Donald Trump's tariffs impacting the economy. Consumer price index rose by 2.7% year over year, with a core inflation increase driven by food and energy prices. Economists expect continued price pressures with new tariffs and restrictions on trade expected to take effect in August.

stories.headline: What we know about victims in KY church, airport shootings
stories.summary: A Lexington man went on a crime spree that ended with three people injured and three dead, including himself. The victims include Beverly Gumm, wife of Richmond Road Baptist pastor Jerry Gumm, her sister Christina Combs, and others shot and injured during the incidents. The story highlights victims' backgrounds and relationships, including Beverly Gumm's struggles and family details.

stories.headline: Ex-girlfriend sought restraining order before KY shooting
stories.summary: For the past three months, the relationship between Guy House and his girlfriend had deteriorated. House had taken her driver's license, gone through her phone to see who she was calling, checked to see if she was at work, and stalked her at a neighborhood pool. The woman called the police and filed an emergency protective order. On July 13, House snapped, shot a police officer, then killed his former partner and her family members at Richmond Road Baptist Church. Two others were wounded and the shooting victim's identity was revealed.

stories.headline: Redistricting draws attention
stories.summary: Texas redistricting is under scrutiny as President Donald Trump highlighted the potential for the state to gain seats in the U.S. House of Representatives, but with significant risks involved. Republicans are pushing for new congressional boundaries favoring incumbents, while Democrats oppose the plans. The political stakes remain high as the Texas legislature debates the redistricting process in a special session.

stories.headline: Scientists cook up food sensor
stories.summary: Researchers at the University of Texas at Dallas have developed a portable food safety sensor, called READ FWDx, designed to detect contaminants and foodborne bacteria in real time. The device can measure multiple parameters including bacteria, gluten, pesticides, blood pressure, and other health indicators. The innovation aims to improve food safety across processing facilities and home kitchens by providing rapid and accurate contamination detection.

stories.headline: Surging demand ahead for now
stories.summary: Apartment demand in Dallas is currently outpacing new construction, with markets like Arlington, Plano, Frisco, and McKinney posting high numbers of new occupancies in 2025. Approximately 12,000 new apartments have been delivered in Dallas-Fort Worth this year, with 13,500 occupied. Despite uncertainty about the future leasing pace, experts note persistent strong demand and ongoing development efforts, although rising rental costs remain a concern.

stories.headline: Texans helping Texans
stories.summary: Volunteers are aiding flood victims in Texas by digging out and cleaning up after the severe flooding caused by the Guadalupe River overflowing. Efforts by local residents and volunteer groups are focused on mass cleanup across affected counties like Kerr County. The flooding resulted from heavy rains on July 4th and has caused significant property damage and debris that requires extensive remediation.

stories.headline: US weapons ready to ship in deal to supply Ukraine via NATO
stories.summary: The United States has prepared a deal to supply Ukraine with patriot air defense systems, missiles, and ammunition through NATO allies. The arms will be sold under an arms deal brokered with President Donald Trump ensuring Ukraine can defend itself from Russian attacks. Most weapons are immediately ready to ship to Ukraine to aid ongoing military efforts, though officials remain cautious about on-going negotiations. NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte emphasized the importance of supporting Ukraine for regional defense.

stories.headline: Inflation accelerated in June as tariffs pushed up prices
stories.summary: The consumer price index rose 2.7% year over year in June, the fastest pace since February, driven largely by the inflationary effects of President Donald Trump's tariffs. Core inflation, excluding food and energy, also increased moderately. The data reflects pressure on the economy via tariff-related price hikes and indicates policymakers face challenges in managing inflation while keeping interest rates steady.

stories.headline: California disaster aid stuck as Newsom, Congress feud
stories.summary: House Speaker Mike Johnson blamed Governor Gavin Newsom and California officials for delays in federal disaster aid approval following last winter's Los Angeles wildfires. Johnson suggested bureaucratic processes and political tensions were hindering the release of critical aid. Newsom, who has clashed politically with the Trump administration, was cited as a key reason for the hold-up. The delay has drawn criticism amid requests for financial support related to wildfire damages, with lawmakers calling attention to the urgent need for assistance.

stories.headline: Railyards deal dies; Republic FC commits to stadium
stories.summary: Sacramento Republic FC announced that a group of residents and labor advocates successfully halted the expansion of a special taxing district in the Railyards, but the team remains committed to building a new stadium there. The city council recent decision withdrew the proposal involving a large chunk of land and expected tax increases to cover development costs. Despite this setback, the team president stated the intention to continue moving forward with their stadium plans in the Railyards district, aiming for a 2027 opening.

stories.headline: Trump's megabill creating new roadblocks for immigrants
stories.summary: Immigrants in Houston face difficulties as President Trump's 'Big, Beautiful Bill' introduces new administrative hurdles and fees for asylum seekers. This has led to rejected requests and legal challenges, with some immigrants forced to pay nearly $3,000 in fees. The bill complicates the asylum application process and delays reconsideration of removal orders, adding strain to immigrant families and advocates.

stories.headline: Over 800 teachers left HISD in 2024-25
stories.summary: Houston Independent School District experienced a 48% increase in teacher departures since the state takeover in June 2023, with over 800 teachers leaving between August 2024 and May 2025. This surge is attributed to higher expectations for instruction and employee performance, requiring more rigorous evaluations and accountability. HISD acknowledges the shift and emphasizes the importance of change to better serve students.

stories.headline: 46 minutes between alert, evacuation
stories.summary: Local agencies face safety challenges as Texans seek to rebuild in floodplains after devastating flash floods along Texas rivers that caused over 130 deaths. Experts warn about the limited regulation on floodplain development and the need for better disaster preparedness as Texas deals with flash flood warnings and evacuation challenges, particularly at Camp Mystic where 46 minutes elapsed between alert and evacuation.

stories.headline: Private investors want to make USF area a tech hub
stories.summary: Local leaders and private investors are working to revitalize the University of South Florida (USF) area, known for high poverty rates, by transforming it into a technology hub. The 19-square-mile area includes USF, Moffitt Cancer Center, and Busch Gardens. Efforts emphasize creating a vibrant community with tech employers and mixed-use developments, revitalizing what was previously a low-income neighborhood. Key figures like Jonathan Davila discuss their vision for a thriving, innovative district to attract talent and investment.

stories.headline: The most personal care isn’t billed
stories.summary: Nurse navigators at St. Joseph’s Children’s Hospital provide free support to parents of children with complex medical needs. The story focuses on Sienna Yeager, a child born with a heart defect and rare genetic condition, whose parents received extensive help including guidance on feeding tubes from a nurse navigator named Natalie Jackson. This personalized, compassionate care helps guide families through complicated medical challenges without charging for these services.

stories.headline: Will Rays owner’s wallet match our dreams?
stories.summary: Baseball columnist John Romano discusses the challenges and hopes for Tampa Bay Rays fans amid potential changes in team ownership. The article highlights the patience required in baseball's long season and minor leagues and considers whether new deep-pocketed owners might bring a better experience to Tampa Bay's baseball fans. The article reflects on the history of baseball in Tampa Bay and the potential for future improvements with new ownership.

stories.headline: Prosecutor to fight Zeigler’s release
stories.summary: An Orlando-area state attorney has decided that recent DNA testing results are not strong enough to release Tommy Zeigler from death row after nearly 49 years. The state argues that Zeigler's absence of family members' DNA in bloodstains on his clothes does not conclusively prove his innocence. Zeigler's lawyers submitted a two-year-old DNA analysis arguing he could not have committed the murders. The state's attorney contends the evidence is insufficient to overturn convictions or vacate Zeigler's death sentence, as the case has been previously reviewed.

stories.headline: Shoes on at security? Your next KCI flight might be faster
stories.summary: The Transportation Security Administration has eliminated the 'shoes-off' policy at many U.S. airports, including Kansas City International Airport, starting July 8. This change, part of DHS's efforts to modernize and enhance traveler experience across the nation, is expected to significantly reduce wait times at TSA checkpoints. The policy previously required travelers to remove shoes during security screening.

stories.headline: Tiffaney Whitt leads change at Hope Leadership KC
stories.summary: Tiffaney Whitt, a leader with a background in criminal justice and education, has been appointed as the new executive director of Hope Leadership KC. This organization focuses on improving the lives of Kansas City residents through community impact projects. Whitt’s leadership style and passion for teaching and learning have made her well-regarded in the community. The interviews and episodes about her journey and impact are available on the KKFI platform.

stories.headline: What Trump’s EV policy shifts mean for Panasonic in Kansas
stories.summary: Panasonic may experience delays in full production at its De Soto EV battery plant due to President Donald Trump’s new federal tax credit and spending package, which eliminates certain tax credits for new EV purchases and uses. Despite these policy shifts, the company remains cautiously optimistic about medium- to long-term growth in the U.S. EV market as it monitors policy developments and market responses closely.

stories.headline: Panasonic’s $4B EV battery plant opens in Johnson County
stories.summary: Panasonic has officially opened its $4 billion electric vehicle battery plant in De Soto, Kansas, marking one of the biggest investments in the Kansas region. The opening ceremony included local and federal officials participating in a traditional sake barrel-breaking ritual symbolizing new beginnings. The plant, a 4.7 million-square-foot facility, is expected to be a key part of the growing EV market, though Panasonic acknowledges potential delays due to recent changes in federal tax credit policies.
people: U.S. Ambassador of Japan to the United States, Shigeo Yamada

stories.headline: GOP chair predicts turning PBC red
stories.summary: The chairman of the Republican Party of Palm Beach County predicts GOP voters will outnumber Democrats in the next midterm election, aiming to flip the county’s congressional seat in 2026. Carl Cascio, party leader since 2025, indicated the GOP holds potential to close the current voter registration gap through efforts such as purging inactive voters and attracting conservative voters post-COVID. The Republican Party expects to narrow the election margins based on recent voter registration statistics and election results.

stories.headline: Post wins top journalism award for its grand jury coverage in Epstein case
stories.summary: The Palm Beach Post received a Southeast regional journalism award for nearly five years of investigative coverage unveiling details of Jeffrey Epstein's trafficking ring that led to dozens of victims being discovered. The Green Eyeshade Award honors investigative editor Holly Baltz and reporter teams for their extensive reporting on the Epstein case, court activity, and associated crimes over many years. Their work highlighted Epstein’s crimes, plea deals, and ongoing effects of his trafficking network.

stories.headline: As anger mounts over Epstein’s ‘client list,’ where’s Ghislaine Maxwell?
stories.summary: Ghislaine Maxwell, sentenced to 20 years in prison for her role in Jeffrey Epstein’s sex trafficking network, remains a focus as people seek confirmation of a list of Epstein's clients supposedly imprisoned in Florida. Maxwell, serving time at a federal correctional institution, is the only known person who could verify the existence of the list. Epstein allegedly ran a sex trafficking ring spanning multiple states until his arrest and death in custody in 2019. Maxwell was found guilty of multiple sex trafficking charges and continues to serve her sentence while the controversy persists.

stories.headline: Unfazed Putin will keep fighting
stories.summary: President Vladimir Putin intends to keep fighting in Ukraine until the West engages on his terms for peace, despite tough sanctions and demands amid Russian advances. Putin, who ordered Russian troops into Ukraine in February 2022, believes Russia's economy and military are strong enough to endure further Western measures. He rejected a ceasefire on July 14 and threatened more sanctions on Russia if a peace deal is not reached within 50 days. Kremlin sources say Putin will continue the war under pressure from the West, aiming to achieve his goals in Ukraine.

stories.headline: ‘A BLACK HOLE’ Attorneys say they still can’t reach clients in Alligator Alcatraz
stories.summary: Two weeks since Alligator Alcatraz opened, lawyers say the detention facility has been something of a black box, with detainees going in and little information coming out, except for outgoing calls from the site. Attorneys say Florida's pop-up detention facility at the Florida-run center for migrants in the Everglades has been difficult to reach, with lawyers struggling to schedule legal visitations despite state assurances. The facility processes detainees who quickly move through the federal system, complicating legal access and support.

stories.headline: Family of woman slain in 2019 Florida Keys crash blames Tesla’s Autopilot for her death
stories.summary: The family of a young woman killed in a 2019 crash in the Florida Keys attributes her death to a Tesla vehicle's Autopilot system. The crash occurred when the woman was standing next to her vehicle as it started to accelerate without her control. Tesla and legal experts counter that the accident was caused by a distracted driver and not the Autopilot system. The driver of the other vehicle faced legal consequences tied to the crash, with no direct evidence linking Tesla's Autopilot to the incident.

stories.headline: Sharks might be spending less time off Florida. That’s actually not good
stories.summary: New research shows that the migratory behavior of six shark species within the Mid-Atlantic Bight region may be changing, with some sharks possibly spending less time off Florida. This reduction in presence could have catastrophic ramifications on the entire food web. The study tracked sharks from Massachusetts to North Carolina, highlighting the ecological impact of their altered patterns.

stories.headline: Greater Miami catches up with NYC in one more way: high income inequality
stories.summary: The Miami area has matched New York City's less-flattering superlatives by tying with NYC for having the worst income inequality in the country's 10 most-populous metro areas. This growing gap is driven by an influx of high earners who live here, combined with many workers in lower-wage jobs who have not seen their incomes keep pace. The COVID-19 pandemic intensified wealth disparities, with rising local prices, especially for housing, putting financial pressure on South Florida residents.

stories.headline: Bipartisan effort for good of Pa.
stories.summary: Senator Dave McCormick and Governor Josh Shapiro showed bipartisan cooperation at Carnegie Mellon University during the Pennsylvania Energy and Innovation Summit. They set aside political disagreements to focus on advancing technology, government, and energy initiatives, pushing for Keystone State to lead in the energy and AI sectors. The collaboration aims to promote prosperity and innovation for Pennsylvania's future amid significant new investments.

stories.headline: Companies delivered on projects
stories.summary: Companies involved with the Energy and Innovation Summit have made progress on numerous projects related to AI and energy infrastructure in Pennsylvania. These include major investments like Google’s $25 billion commitment to build data centers and Blackstone's plans to develop a data center and natural gas power plants in Northeast Pennsylvania. Despite the impressive figures, the accounting of the investments and timelines remains complex.

stories.headline: TRUMP: $92B INVESTMENT USHERS IN PA. 'GOLDEN AGE'
stories.summary: At the Pennsylvania Energy and Innovation Summit at Carnegie Mellon University, President Donald Trump announced a $92 billion investment by 20 companies in AI and energy infrastructure in Pennsylvania. This significant investment is seen as ushering in a 'golden age' for the state, highlighting Pittsburgh as a leader in the AI revolution and emphasizing the importance of innovation for future growth.

stories.headline: Lack of state funds to shutter 2 homeless vet facilities
stories.summary: Two homeless veteran housing facilities in Wisconsin, in Chippewa Falls and Green Bay, are set to close by September 30 due to a lack of funding from the state legislature. Republicans did not allocate budget funds to support these centers, despite promises to veterans. The Wisconsin Department of Veterans Affairs expressed disappointment and concern over the impact on veterans at risk of homelessness, and continues to assist veterans in connecting with resources. The closures highlight ongoing challenges in delivering essential veteran services amid funding shortfalls.

stories.headline: Lawsuit: Pause in school funding ‘unlawful’
stories.summary: Wisconsin, along with Washington, D.C. and 23 other states, sued the Trump administration over its decision to withhold over $6 billion in K-12 and adult education funding. The funds are distributed under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, supporting various programs for children and adult learners. The suspension, termed unlawful by the lawsuit, is said to contradict prior congressional approval and presidential priorities. State education officials emphasized that schools depend on these funds to serve students, and the federal pause could impact families and communities negatively.

stories.headline: ARE YOU SEEING MORE FIREFLIES? Or did you get used to seeing fewer?
stories.summary: Scientists have reported an overall decline in the firefly population globally, but many Milwaukee residents are seeing their backyards light up with fireflies this summer. The insects are active in parks and forests across the area, raising questions about whether we are witnessing a resurgence or if higher visibility is misleading. Rainfall and favorable conditions recently have supported firefly larvae growth, though habitat loss and human impact remain threats. Conservation efforts continue, with local educators training citizens to monitor fireflies through initiatives like the Firefly Atlas.

stories.headline: West Ada schools tighten rules after DEI uproar
stories.summary: The West Ada School Board voted to change its policy surrounding classroom decorum, including prohibiting teachers and school administrators from posting banners or flags with political implications in public schools. This change came after controversy involving a poster with the words “Everyone is welcome here” and a teacher removed it from a classroom. The board asked to take down posters that include images of hands in different skin tones under an argument related to political expression in schools. The new policy passed with four votes for and no votes against but with one absent, seeking to regulate political signs in classrooms.

stories.headline: Boise City Council might ask voters for $11 million tax increase. Here’s why
stories.summary: The Boise City Council is considering asking voters to approve an open-space levy on the November ballot. Council members plan a resolution for a voluntary tax increase for property owners. Property owners would pay just under $10 more annually on a $100,000 property value, according to Mayor Lauren McLean. Boise commissioners have used previous open-space levies to acquire land and develop parks. Currently, there is about $1 million of leftover levy funding. The existing 2015 levy raised $10 million for parks, trails, and land purchases. Council members hope new developments will propose new parks that the city would dedicate. A simple majority of voters would need to approve a new levy, which has historically received strong support.

stories.headline: Data show big changes in fast-growing Meridian
stories.summary: Twenty years ago, Meridian was considered a bedroom community where people lived but not worked. In 2002, the city had over 23,000 working people but fewer than 3,800 worked locally. Most commuted elsewhere, mainly to Boise. New data from the Idaho Department of Labor and U.S. Census Bureau shows that Meridian’s growth has pushed west and commercial development has accelerated beyond Boise. Meridian has added jobs, boosted wages, and attracted employers to set up locally, cutting workers’ commute times. More residents work in the city than ever before. While Boise’s share of jobs has declined, Meridian’s is growing faster than other cities in the West, becoming more self-sufficient and importing more workers than it exports.

stories.headline: To save feral cats, Boise’s soccer club helping family
stories.summary: Tracy Brodt was teaching her teenage daughter to drive in the parking lot of the Western Idaho Fairgrounds in 2014 when she spotted a woman feeding stray cats near Les Bois Park. After more than a decade of diligence and care, Brodt has helped bring that feral cat population down from around 200 to less than 50.
